location: BOW SLEEPING BERTH OF A 39 FT SAILBOAT

text: OUR MAN is sound asleep as the boat moves up and down thr the small waves that we can hear through the hull of the boat. A terrible crunching and ripping noise echoes through the small space. OUR MAN immediately opens his eyes to the so of rushing water. OUR MAN jumps out of the berth and as his feet hit the gr they land in several inches of water inside the cabin of boat. He jumps up. As he looks down several small white knock- Keds kids sneakers are floating in the water. OUR MAN rushes towards the back of the boat, as he enters main cabin he sees a four foot long gash in the side of t boat. There is water pouring into the cabin from the bottom of gash. The gash is located right at the navigation table of the where all the electronics are located. The water is pouri in around and through the electronics including the GPS, RADAR, RADIO, and SATELLITE PHONE. OUR MAN jumps through the rushing water and climbs up the steps to the cockpit of the boat.

Through the early morning light he now sees what has happened. A massive shipping container that had fallen off a cargo is almost completely submerged in the water and is now st to the boat through the gash in the side of the boat. Thousands of the white shoes are floating in the water an emptying from a hole in the container. OUR MAN jumps into action. The boat is heeling (being pushed at an angle due to the pressure on the sails) towards the side of the boat that gash is on allowing the water to flow into the boat. But first he must get the container unhooked from the gas it will sink the boat very soon unless he intervenes. He pushes against it with his feet, kicking. Nothing. Gets o boat hook and tries to use that as a lever. Nothing. Trie kicking and pushing again. Nothing. The water continues to pour into the boat. So he turns and opens a storage locker under the cockpit seats and pulls out a long line (rope). He jumps down onto the half sunk container, lashes a line around one end. Slips several times almost falling into t water. He can now really see that the container is totally lodge place. He jumps back onto the boat and heads down the stairs in the cabin that is now filled with several feet of water. white kids shoes are everywhere. He wades through the water to a front storage locker. He opens it and pulls out a large case that has LIFERAFT wri in red letters on it. But instead of taking the case upst he opens the case and lifts the raft up and grabs a yello looking sack that is stored behind the raft. He heads back up onto the deck. He jumps back down onto the container and takes a metal l that is sticking out of the yellow sack and ties the long rope to it. He now stops and looks around and tries to calmly analyze situation before he takes another move. He looks up at th sails and the wind direction indicator at the top of the mast. He scans the horizon. Finally he shakes the contents out of the yellow bag, it fills with air. It is a small parachute of some kind. (It a SEA ANCHOR, a device that is used in extreme weather, t help stabilize a boat by dragging it under the water. The parachute holds the boat back as huge waves thrash it) He shakes out the sea anchor and holds it over the edge of storage container into the water. The water catches in the chute and starts pulling the rop that is spooled on the deck. The rope unspools, as he jum back onto the boat and gets behind the steering wheel wai for the rope to run out. The coil of rope gets shorter and shorter and finally it all gone. In one extremely loud and jarring move the container rips of the hull of the boat as OUR MAN turns the wheel of the boat away from the container. He is free. He immediately turns the boat onto the other tack (the opposite point of sail) so that the boat is now leaning t other direction so that the gash is up in the air slightl that water is no longer coming in through the hole. He immediately looks back at the container that he is lea in the distance and seems to be making a decision. He turns around, scans the horizon. Looks down into the that is filled with water, then reaches out to the lines controlling the sails and begins to turn the boat around towards the container... what is he doing? He sails the boat back towards the container but at this point of sail he is not always able to heel the boat enou to keep the water from coming in, so the water continues pour in every so often. He finally approaches the shipping container again. It si in the water looking like every inch the destructive forc that it has been. He looks back up at the wind indicator again trying to ga an approach strategy. He turns the boat abruptly into the wind and comes up nex the side of the submerged container. He stalls out his boat, the water starts coming into the again as the boat levels, he jumps back onto the containe

He pulls out a knife from the holster on his belt loop an cuts the rope that attached the sea anchor to the contain As he is reaching out for the rope he drops his knife and rolls off of the container into the ocean. OUR MAN recovers and takes the rope and jumps back on his boat just as it begins to drift away.

He now begins to pull the sea anchor back towards him. It a struggle. As he is pulling, he keeps looking behind him down into the cabin at the water that is coming in throug the gash. But he must get the sea anchor back on board. He pulls an pulls and finally the large orange parachute appears from below the surface like some sort of fish net. He struggle empty the water from it and get it into the cockpit. The second it is completely back on board he jumps up and turns the wheel and gets the boat under way again back on point of sail that raises the gash above the waterline. As he sails away he turns around and takes one last look the container. The camera pulls back to reveal the side of the boat tha ripped open by the collision.

location: CABIN OF BOAT NAVIGATION TABLE AREA

text: The rack of high tech equipment is dripping with water an totally dead. OUR MAN picks up the radio receiver and tur the switch, nothing. A plastic bag of corn flakes cereal floats by him. He loo over at the food cabinet that is partially under water. But the open gash in the hull that is next to the equipme shows the ocean flying by and he decides that is clearly first priority.
OUR MAN leans over the side of the boat and looks at the ripped fiberglass hull more closely. It looks terrible.

OUR MAN is ripping apart a teak bench with a hammer. He tries to cut the pieces of wood into long strips. He digs around in a bin that is just above the water leve He pulls out three cans of fiber glass raw materials.

We see our man mix up the fiberglass and hang over the si of the boat and attach the strips of wood to the boat the start fiberglassing over the strips. It is perilous work as he is hanging over the edge of the boat as it sails along.
He does some of the same work from inside the cabin. He i starting to make some progress. There is now seven inches new makeshift hull that is drying.

OUR MAN starts in on a built in hand pump that will pump water from the cabin. He has shoved a long mop handle int the pump for better leverage. He checks the compass. WE SEE SEVERAL SHOTS OF HIM PUMPING AND FIBERGLASSING.
Night is falling. OUR MAN eats a can of soup while sittin and staring out at the ocean.
OUR MAN tries to sleep as the water in the cabin sloshes around. FADE TO BLACK.
Pumping. Fiberglassing. Eating. Pumping. Fiberglassing. Eating. Pumping. Fiberglassing...he almost falls over the edge. Eating.
OUR MAN sits and stares out at the endless ocean. He lays down and falls asleep. FADE TO BLACK.

OUR MAN stands in front of the gash. The repair is comple Although it looks like hell, it is watertight. He is plea He looks down at his feet and the floor of the cabin can be seen as the water is gone. The wooden decking is start to warp up but there is no standing water. His eyes drift over to the navigation and electronics tab EXT. BOAT - DECK —- BRIGHT MORNING There is no wind, the ocean is flat. OUR MAN takes down t sails and the boat comes to a stop. As it does the repair gash dips below the waterline and he looks on to see if i will hold water. It does.

OUR MAN has laid out and secured down all of the charts, maps, navigation books, and is bringing up pieces of electronics one by one to dry in the glaring midday sun. He zeroes in on the radio. He starts to take it apart. Th salt has begun to corrode the inner parts of the radio. O man looks around. He grabs a container of fresh water and pours it over the radio parts. He puts it down to dry in the sun. He goes over and starts to collect the maps. He sits down with the pile and searches through to find one that corresponds with his last coordinates. The two electronic GPS systems sit in a pile on the deck useless. By the look on OUR MAN'S face he has been relying on the too closely in life. He is lost.
He goes over to a shelf filled with wet books. He scans a takes out a book titled AN INTRODUCTION TO CELESTIAL NAVIGATION. He sits and begins looking at it.

(static noise... crackle) (foreign language) When are you going to get here?  OUR MAN immediately looks up like he has heard a ghost. RADIO VOICE (CONT’D) (foreign language) That's right. OUR MAN drops everything and scrambles up the stairs and stares at the radio waiting to see if it comes to life ag The light blinks. RADIO VOICE (CONT’D) (static... static) OUR MAN picks up the mic and presses the button.
This is the Virginia Jean, are you there over? Nothing.
This is the Virginia Jean with an S.0.S. call over? Nothing.

This is the Virginia Jean with an S.0.S. call over? Nothing... The powerlight goes off on the radio... it’s d OUR MAN hears something, he looks around, the wind is starting to pick up and ripple the still water. He tries bounce back from the near miss on the radio. He goes and collects all the loose components from the de and gets the boat ready to sail again. The sails are up and he has got things going again. Spiri are up. As dusk begins to fall OUR MAN looks out across the ocean there is a dark cloud on the far distant horizon. He look down at the disabled weather radio. He has no idea if it’s a small rain shower or something f worse. INSERT TITLE CARD: ACT II (Man vs. Nature)

OUR MAN is down below preparing dinner when the rain star hitting the deck above his head. It starts softly then bu to a downpour. He sticks his head out of the doorway to l at the horizon, there is no wind building, he is relieved He cooks some beans on the stove. He pours himself a scotch. Settles in to read The Introduction to Celestial Navigati as the rain falls. The boat is once again watertight and quickly falls asleep. FADE TO BLACK.
OUR MAN is asleep. The bright sun comes into the cabin an slowly wakes. He looks around realizing that was his firs really good night of sleep in some time.
OUR MAN has got the gas stove working again and is making himself a cup of coffee.
OUR MAN is enjoying his coffee looking out across the wat He zeroes in on a small patch of wind that is dancing acr the surface. It is beautiful but somehow ominous.

OUR MAN is on his hands and knees struggling to get behin the swamped engine to a massive bank of large capacity batteries. They are corroded and waterlogged. He struggle bring one out and up onto the deck.

As he comes back up from below carrying the battery he lo across to the horizon and notices terrible looking storm clouds in the extreme distance. His face registers severe concern. The thunderheads reach miles into the sky.  10. OUR MAN looks around at the boat to see what to do next. is still holding the large battery. He looks down at it i his hands. He hurls it over the edge and heads back down below.

As OUR MAN goes through these preparations he begins to s to himself. The song starts out too low to hear, but then grows. Loading up potable water from the sink tanks into large portable water carriers. Changing the sails to smaller storm sails. Looking out at the horizon as the front comes closer. Down below stowing all loose objects away. Checking the charts/maps to try to place himself. Going into the bathroom and shaving. Checking the fiberglass over the repaired spot. Checking the placement of the life raft and repacking the anchor next to it. Back up top looking out at the storm. The waves are start to pick up. OUR MAN stops, looks around at his little boat, checking see what else needs to be done. He goes over and checks the auto steering device one more time. The clouds are now blocking out the sun and it feel though night is falling.

He is back below prepping his foul weather gear. As he st looking at the jacket the boat gets thrown abruptly in on direction and OUR MAN falls/gets tossed over into the navigation table. The charts come down on top of him. He sits on the ground the boat begins to get rocked far more violently. He can laugh to himself as he knows things are about to get a wh lot worse.  11. (During a storm like this it cannot be underplayed how lo intense, varied, and downright frightening the sounds of storm hitting a small boat are. From the waves hitting th hull, to the wind in the sails and rigging, to the genera pressures put on every element of the ship it is difficul explain. The sound design during this sequence will be of utmost importance and will play relentlessly through the storm sequence. ) OUR MAN stands up and the boat really starts rocking. He struggles to put on the foul weather gear. When he is ful dressed he looks up through the shut doorway out into the deck. It looks and sounds pretty nasty. He opens the door and the fury of the storm comes into fu effect. He struggles up the stairs and out into the cockpit. Wave are starting to build from twelve to fifteen feet and the wind is gusting at thirty knots. The boat appears to be handling the storm well so far but OUR MAN looks up at th sails and clearly he has too much sail up. He is going to have to change the sails in these conditions. Before he does that though he goes back to the auto pilot checks the compass to make sure he is keeping course at 6 degrees North.

Then down he goes to the cabin to get the new storm sail. As he enters the cabin the sounds totally change but are almost more frightening as the stresses the boat is under amplified by the hull. The cabin is now really thrashing and forth. He struggles to the front of the boat and pull out a small sail bag. “STORM JIB” is printed on the sail He then goes into another closet and gets out a storm har with a large clip on it. He puts the harness on and heads back out onto the deck. Each time he walks back and forth through the cabin the pattern of the movements of the boat change. There is no steady flow to how the boat is handling the storm at this point. He steadies himself one last time before going back out i the storm.  12.

The weather is getting worse by the minute. He looks thro the rain and spray up to the mast. The boat is almost lay on its side. He clips the harness clip onto the rail and heads forward change the sails. (Changing sails in these type of conditions yet alone at night is an extremely hazardous undertaking. The boat is thrashing back and forth due to the waves and the wind is crushing the sails that he is trying to take down.) OUR MAN struggles to take the head sail down and get it i the boat. Then he moves back to the main sail. This is a greater challenge. Waves are now regularly coming right across the deck of t boat and risk washing him overboard. With each new wave t situation seems to worsen. He gets the main sail down and just as he is folding it t bring it down below a massive wave comes across the deck sweeps OUR MAN over the edge of the boat and into the wat

The camera is now under the water with OUR MAN. A portion the massive main sail in also under the water with him. I strangely quiet. Then we see OUR MAN’s face and see that he is conscious b panicking to get back on board. The storm harness is saving his life but is also risking drown him. The boat is dragging him along in the water an can’t seem to get back aboard. He gasps up for air as the surface comes close for a mome and then he is back down below and risking drowning. Finally he starts to pull himself back towards the boat u the leash from the harness and when he can grabbing the s that is now almost completely in the water. He pulls himself back up onto the deck but must finish th original task. He folds the sail into the cabin, struggli terribly, then finally is able to install the small storm sail.  13.
As he turns to head back into the cabin he looks for a mo out to sea into the darkness and sees the waves have grow at least twenty-five feet high.

OUR MAN comes down the stairs into the cabin and slams sh the hatch. The sound goes from total chaos to controlled chaos. He pulls off his soaked foul weather gear and falls to th floor exhausted. Suddenly he jumps up and throws up a goo gallon of sea water into the sink. He falls back down to floor and passes out. The storm rages on as he slides from side to side across floor as the boat careens down the face of the waves, one after the next. FADE TO BLACK.

OUR MAN is rudely awoken by the boat feeling like it is falling off a cliff, then landing at the base of a wave w a horrifying crash. He gets thrown across the floor of th cabin and then gets sent in the other direction. He’s up OUR MAN realizes this situation is not improving. He gets and gets out the sea anchor from the storage bin again. H checks through its components then prepares to head back into the storm.

Just as he is about to open up the hatch again he gets th off the steps as the boat starts to go down the face of another massive wave. Although this time, things seem different... very different. Everything goes almost eerily silent as the boat seems to float in the air. Then it skips, then again, then total mayhem as the boat is rolled over. The porthole windows turn blue with water, so do the skyl windows. OUR MAN is hurled to the ceiling of the cabin as temporarily becomes the floor. Then the horrible sound of ripping fiberglass.  14. The boat continues its roll and the floor becomes the flo again as OUR MAN gets thrown around like a rag doll. The boat somewhat stabilizes and before it heads down the next wave OUR MAN goes to the skylight porthole to look u and sees through the early morning light to see what the just happened. He rushes over to a side window and sees a few of the sta (cables that hold up the mast) have ripped from the deck are whipping around. Here comes another massive wave. He braces himself. It’s not as big but the boat is hurtling down the face an sounds as though it may start coming apart. OUR MAN must get out and install the sea anchor. He forgoes putting on any foul weather gear and goes over the steps.

As he comes up the steps and into the cockpit the light o the new day lets him see the size and ferocity of the wav for the first time. The rain and wind have somewhat died but the waves are beyond belief. Trying not to lock up completely from fear OUR MAN makes way to the back of the cockpit, attaches the clip of the anchor to the back of the boat and then, just as he lets cloth parachute go into the water, a massive wave builds behind the boat. A second smaller cross wave comes and pushes the boat sideways and it begins a death-roll.

The cockpit area is now underwater and OUR MAN is doing a he can to stay attached to the boat. He did not attach th storm harness this time so he is free floating into the ocean. The boat does a massive full flip under the water and the noise like nothing else we have heard up to this point. I snapping metal combined with the deep thunder of a fifty wave crashing around him.  15. The boat starts in on a second flip and miraculously he i scooped back up into the cockpit by total luck as the boa rights itself in the trough of the wave. OUR MAN looks around and can’t believe that he is back on boat. He immediately grabs the clip of his storm harness and cl it to the boat. Then he looks around. The mast of the boat is snapped like a toothpick. He look behind him and sees the remains of the mast sinking. He looks at the contact points where the mast was connect to the deck of the boat and sees that at each point a hol the deck has been ripped open. Then he looks down at the connection point and sees that sea anchor is still connected and appears to now be worki With each oncoming wave the boat is now held back by the anchor and it doesn’t speed down the face of the wave.

OUR MAN comes down the steps of the cabin and closes the hatch behind him. Sea water is now dripping and at times pouring in through the holes ripped in the hull and deck the boat. OUR MAN looks around the cabin and starts to prepare for possibility that he may have to abandon ship. His movements around the cabin are made very difficult by each new wave throwing the boat about. After collecting a few things another massive wave comes the sea anchor seems to snap, because the boat is suddenl jolted forward. This causes OUR MAN to be thrown across the cabin and aga the wall in the front V sleeping berth from the opening s He is knocked unconscious and blood starts flowing from h head. FADE TO BLACK.  16.

OUR MAN comes to and he is laying in a significant pool o blood. He is up on the raised bunk but every so often a splash of water is heard. His eyes open and he now sees that the boat is officially sinking. He gets up, but he is pretty messed up so he is not in th hurry he should be in. There is a gash on his forehead. The water is now a solid four feet deep in the cabin. He wades through the main cabin and the storm seems to be calming down some, the boat isn’t quite flying around lik was and the noise has laid off some. OUR MAN methodically goes to the food closet and grabs wh he can. Water is now just pouring in through an enlarged gash on side of the deck. He goes over and pulls out the large liferaft case from t closet and pulls it through the water and tries with all effort he can muster to get it up onto the deck. EXT. BOAT — DECK/OCEAN OUR MAN struggles to get the liferaft over towards the ed of the cockpit. He takes a large security clip and attaches the liferaft the boat. He then hurls it over the edge into the water. The second hits the water the raft explodes open and fills with air exactly as it was designed to do. The waves and wind have definitely lessened in intensity are still making this transfer from the boat to the raft extremely dangerous maneuver. OUR MAN takes one last look around at his sinking ship. He takes the sea anchor clip from the hook on the back of boat and clips it to the liferaft.  17. He looks out into the ocean and does his best to time his leap with the oncoming waves and finally dives into the opening of the raft.

He lets out a good 25 yards of line and looks out from th relative safety of the liferaft back towards his boat. He about to disconnect the rope that connects him to the boa but he looks around the raft at the few items he was able bring with him in the rush. It was not much. He looks out again at the boat and it is riding very low the water but does not seem to be sinking. As he turns around and lays down to think about what to d next he closes his eyes and falls asleep. FADE OUT.

OUR MAN wakes up and the raft is very calm. The storm has passed and the waves have almost completely settled. It is quiet. He suddenly realizes he never unhooked himself from the b He turns and looks out through the entrance flap and his is still floating... barely. The water has come almost up the deck. He’s not quite sure how it is still staying abo the surface. He looks around the raft and decides he needs to get back into the boat as he may be here for awhile. He begins pulling in the rope that is still connecting hi the boat. The raft bumps up against the side of the boat and as he looks into the cabin he sees that the water is almost all way up to the ceiling of the cabin.
He climbs into the submerged cockpit and makes his way do into the cabin.  18.

There is just about a foot of air at the top of the cabin the water has taken over everything else. OUR MAN starts going around the boat and collecting things that could be useful. Each time he goes for a new item he has to dive d below the water and search for it. Remaining canned and packaged foods. An extra water jug. Charts. The Introduction to Celestial Navigation book. A sextant. An expandable boat hook. A small portable gas camping stove. Clothes. A first-aid kit. As he loads the first aid kit into the bag he remembers t nasty gash on his forehead. He reaches up and touches it, there is still a large gash open, and winces. He thinks about it for a second and with the risk for infection about as high as it could possibly be he decide take some action. He gets the kit and wades back through the boat towards t bathroom. He opens the door and looks into the mirror. He sees the extent of the gash. He takes out a bottle of hydrogen peroxide and pours it into the cut. It bubbles. The water is up to his shoulders. He then is about to apply a butterfly bandage to the woun but as he is doing so the boat makes a severe groan and l as if it is about to go under. He looks around. The boat groans again then settles. OUR MAN finishes putting the bandage on his head and then hurries through the water to get the hell out of the boat  19. He grabs the bag with all the stuff he has collected. Tak one last look around and heads up and off the boat. One last look around.

OUR MAN settles into the tiny raft and looks back at the boat. It still refuses to go down. Finally, what sounds like a very large balloon popping. T boat begins to roll over and then turns to go under. OUR MAN reaches out and unclips the raft from the boat. T boat finally goes under.
An extreme pull back wide shot of the tiny liferaft total alone in the middle of the impossibly vast ocean. ACT III (Man vs. Self)

(This will be the first of a series of more abstract shot placed throughout the final act.) The camera is in the water looking back up at the liferaf towards the surface. The shot will move in to a close up the bottom of the raft. There is a small amount of algae starting to grow on the bottom of the raft. As the camera gets very close on the algae out of the corner of the fra comes a tiny small fish, no larger than a minnow, that sw up to the algae and starts to eat it.

(A few specifics about the liferaft. It is an octagon. Th base, or floor is filled with air but is quite flexible. the days go on it will become more so as it starts to deflate. There is a tent over the whole thing that protec from the extreme sun during the day and the cold and wind night. This tent is held up by inflated supports.) OUR MAN is sitting in the liferaft looking around at the clutter. What to do?  20. He sifts through the bag and takes out the charts, the sextant, and the book about celestial navigation. Now he some time, and he finally better figure out where the hel the world he is. Eating canned beans. Drinking a small amount of water from the jug. Reading the book and trying to take a few rudimentary readings with the sextant. The sun is setting. OUR MAN looks out the doorway of the liferaft at the hori FADE TO BLACK.

OUR MAN wakes up and his face is displeased. He looks and feels around and he sees that there is a couple of inches water in the raft at the low points, which are of course where his body is. We begin to realize life in this raft going to be pretty miserable. Reading the book some more. Looking at his watch. It’s almost noon. Doing a reading with the sextant using the sun at exactly noon. He writes down the numbers then checks in the book does some fairly simple calculations. He gets excited as seems like he may be finally for the first time in his li be figuring this out. He scrambles through the mess in on the bags and takes out a stack of charts. He rifles throu them and pulls out one. He checks the compass points, the gets out a pen and makes a mark. This is where he is. The camera pulls back from that mark and gets wider till see that he is literally in the middle of the Indian Ocea OUR MAN zeroes in on several lines that are around him on chart, marks for shipping lanes, and he tries to figure o what direction he is traveling in with his compass. He looks around, back at the chart, and jumps to action. He shimmies around the edge of the raft and begins to pul the sea anchor. He brings it into the raft. He is heading the correct direction and wants to get going at greater speed.  21.

The camera is again below the raft coming into a close-up the algae on the bottom of the raft. There are now ten or small fish eating the algae. The plants have grown larger well. As the camera gets closer and closer to one of the minnow much larger fish comes darting in from the edge of frame eats the smaller fish. This is startling and cuts into.

OUR MAN is awoken from a nap by something hitting his bac the fish bumping into the bottom of the raft as it ate th little guy. OUR MAN looks around and doesn’t know what it was. Drinks water. Eats. Gets out a small mirror and a razor and shaves. This seem odd choice but OUR MAN seems to be wanting to keep up som level of appearances for his own mental state if nothing else. As he is finishing shaving he hears something. Then again. Oh fuck. He looks out the door across the horizon and it is a perf sunny day. Then the rumbling again. He stands and turns around and looks behind him, across a the far horizon there is a massive thunder head and very skies. Here we go again. OUR MAN looks around the raft and tries to decide what to next. He grabs the sea anchor and launches it back into the wat (A quick note about OUR MAN’s physical condition at this point in the film. He has lost significant weight since t start of the film.  22. The gash on his forehead does not seem to be healing well but it also isn’t infected. He has been trying to stay sh so we can see his face.) OUR MAN also starts battening down everything in the raft he knows it will be getting rough. When all is as prepared as it can be he takes out the cha and does one last reading with the sextant on the sun jus it is getting covered up by the incoming clouds. He does some calculations, cross references the book and marks his progress on the chart. He is moving closer to t marked shipping lanes.

The camera starts on an extreme close up of the algae on bottom of the raft and begins to pull back. We now see hundreds of the small minnows eating the algae. Then we s thirty of the larger fish that are eating the minnows circling below. Then below them there are five or six fis probably two or three feet long circling below at the bot of the chain. As the camera pulls down further away from little ecosystem we see more and more of the oceans’ surf from below and we can see that it is darkening and becomi very stormy.

OUR MAN is about to get the shit beat out of him and he k it. He has done everything he can to prepare for the wors and now he is just sitting on the windward side of the ra listening as the sounds of the storm start picking up. He looks out the window and you can’t see much but what y can see is not good. OUR MAN hangs on as the tent starts to buckle down on him from the force of the wind. Then in between the gusts of wind the raft starts getting thrown at some pretty crazy angles as the waves start to build.

Back at our ocean view the fish seem to have disappeared the raft and sea anchor look stark against the thrash of storm. The sound underwater is silent though, which is a pleasant contrast to the storm above.  23.

This isn’t good. The tent is now about to give way and is being blown down almost on top of OUR MAN. The waves seem to be coming around and over the raft. Then without notice the raft gets flipped over and everyt starts to fill with water as all of his supplies fall on of him and tumble around the raft like a washing machine. The side walls to the raft now crumple and OUR MAN is los the mayhem. The raft finally comes to the bottom of the wave and sett back right side up. It is filled with water. OUR MAN immediately starts bailing out the water using an empty can. After bailing and bailing OUR MAN finally lays into an al fetal position and tries to close his eyes. He opens them and the nightmare continues. They close. Open. Finally close. FADE TO BLACK.
An extreme wide shot of the raft and sea anchor alone at The camera gets closer and closer to the raft but there a no fish to be seen. As the camera goes by the raft:

OUR MAN is laying looking like a battered fighter across raft. The tent has been ripped and almost completely destroyed by the storm. OUR MAN has now lost his protecti from the sun. Also most of his provisions have been eithe swamped, destroyed, or lost overboard. He is clinging to chart and sextant.  24. He opens and eats a food ration packet from the emergency survival kit. He pulls in the sea anchor to try to speed his process towards the shipping lane. He also uses it as a blanket t protect his legs from the sun. He takes the large water jug, tries a sip, and spits it o Salt. Somehow saltwater has made its way into the water j He looks around the lost horizon. He’s totally fucked. He breaks down.
